content: resistance hat a k a multi-size melt-the-ice by jennifer turmel based on the norwegian resistance hat from world war ii read the story here at the wiki commons and here at science norway if you click on the words in blue or ctrl+click they will take you to the story pages materials yarn and needles in size needed to get the gauge you are looking for for example i made the hat in size 3 20 using aran weight yarn and size 7 needles with a gauge of 4 5 sts/inch abbreviations k = knit p = purl kfb = knit front back increases 1 st ssk = slip slip knit left leaning decrease k2tog = knit 2 sts together right leaning decrease the hat is written for 4 circumferences size 1 = 16 size 2 = 18 size 3 = 20 and size 4 = 22 you want a hat circumference that is smaller than your actual head so that it gives you snug warm fit the gauge is for the stockinette section above the ribbing step 1 cast on the number of stitches in the cast on box places 4 markers evenly for example for fingering size 1 you would cast on 29 sts place a marker four times for a total of 116 stitches your beginning of round marker should be a different color or texture step 2 then work 1x1 ribbing k1 p1 around for the dimensions shown in the ribbing box step 3 increase round increase the number of sts indicated for your size per section so for the fingering size 1 in each of your 4 sections you will increase 3 stitches you can do this however it makes sense one option could be to k8 kfb k9 kfb k9 kfb step 4 knit for the total of inches shown in the box step 5 decreases see instructions in box step 6 make tassel cut 3 or 6 long pieces of yarn depending on how thick you want it to be and weave through point so that you are halfway through each piece of yarn you now have 6 or 12 total strands braid these strands to the end knot to secure and trim tassel gauge 8 sts/inch 7 sts/inch 6 sts/inch 5 sts/inch 4 5 sts/inch 4 sts/inch cast on total section total section total section total section
